Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Online tracking: Threat Detection, Measurement and Response

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project develops new technologies for continual, web-scale measurement and rapid defenses against emerging threats to web privacy and security arising from third-party tracking. It draws from the fields of web security, systems, measurement, statistics, and machine learning. The outputs of this project will enable website administrators to find and fix a large class of privacy and security problems. They will help improve existing browser privacy tools. Finally, they will aid regulatory enforcement and contribute to better-informed press reporting on online privacy and security.

This project is driven by two fundamental questions: (i) which privacy and security threats are created or exacerbated by the presence of embedded third party elements? and (ii) how can we automatically detect these problems and develop defensive tools for users and site administrators? The project uses automated web browsing and measurement to generate "third-party threat profiles" for websites, maintain a "web privacy census," and develop a new class of browser privacy tools using machine learning. The project brings transparency to the third-party ecosystem and enables oversight, giving users and developers the upper hand in blocking unwanted tracking and supporting enforcement actions when companies violate established privacy rules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When we use the web, data about us is collected, traded, and put to use in creative ways, with little transparency or accountability. Our project created an open-source tool to reveal these privacy violations. The tool, OpenWPM, has been used in at least twenty-four studies. Since 2016, we have been using OpenWPM to conduct monthly automated privacy audits of the web's top 1 million sites, creating a "web privacy census", which we publicly released. We found numerous HTML features (APIs) being abused for browser fingerprinting, a sneaky type of online tracking: the AudioContext API for audio processing, the Battery Status API, and the WebRTC API for peer-to-peer real-time communication. We also investigated and exposed (1) how users are tracked when viewing emails (2) how personal data is exfiltrated by third-party scripts on websites (3) how tracking companies exchange sensitive user data using "cookie syncing" and (4) how online shoppers who make payments using cryptocurrencies may have their anonymity violated by third parties on those shopping websites.

Our findings directly led to a number of improvements to web privacy. Most immediately, they led to a backlash against web tracking from the press, the public, and web publishers themselves (who were often unaware of the tracking techniques employed by third parties). We helped the public understand these threats through op-eds, blog posts, podcasts, and engagement with the press. Second, browser makers responded to our findings with a number of privacy-enhancing changes. Third, web standards bodies have updated their guidance for the design of new web features to emphasize privacy protection, in part as a result of our research. Fourth, the project's findings have informed regulation and policy making. For example, findings from our project were heavily cited in the Federal Communications Commission's 2016 broadband privacy rules. We presented two of our papers at the Federal Trade Commission's PrivacyCon conference, and one of our papers was selected for the Privacy Papers for Policy Makers list. Finally, the project has provided opportunities for research mentoring of numerous graduate and undergraduate students.
